From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about Lent in Western Christianity. For Lent in Eastern
Christianity, see [Great Lent](/wiki/Great_Lent "Great Lent"). For other uses,
see [Lent (disambiguation)](/wiki/Lent_\(disambiguation\) "Lent
\(disambiguation\)").

**Lent** ([Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin"): **Quadragesima** : _Fortieth_) is a
solemn religious observance in the Christian [liturgical
calendar](/wiki/Liturgical_calendar "Liturgical calendar") that begins on [Ash
Wednesday](/wiki/Ash_Wednesday "Ash Wednesday") and ends approximately six
weeks later, before [Easter Sunday](/wiki/Easter "Easter"). The purpose of
Lent is the preparation of the believer for Easter through
[prayer](/wiki/Christian_prayer "Christian prayer"), doing
[penance](/wiki/Penance "Penance"), [mortifying the
flesh](/wiki/Mortification_of_the_flesh "Mortification of the flesh"),
[repentance](/wiki/Repentance_\(theology\) "Repentance \(theology\)") of sins,
[almsgiving](/wiki/Almsgiving "Almsgiving"), and [self-
denial](/wiki/Asceticism "Asceticism").[1] This event is observed in the
[Anglican](/wiki/Anglican_Communion "Anglican Communion"), [Eastern
Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox "Eastern Orthodox"), [Oriental
Orthodox](/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox "Oriental Orthodox"),
[Lutheran](/wiki/Lutheran "Lutheran"), [Methodist](/wiki/Methodist
"Methodist"), and [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic "Catholic") Churches.[2][3][4]
Some [Anabaptist](/wiki/Anabaptist "Anabaptist") and
[evangelical](/wiki/Evangelical "Evangelical") churches also observe the
Lenten season.[5][6] Its institutional purpose is heightened in the annual
commemoration of [Holy Week](/wiki/Holy_Week "Holy Week"), marking the death,
burial, and [resurrection of Jesus](/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus "Resurrection
of Jesus"), which recalls the tradition and events of the [New
Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament") beginning on [Palm
Sunday](/wiki/Palm_Sunday "Palm Sunday"), further climaxing on Jesus'
[crucifixion](/wiki/Crucifixion "Crucifixion") on [Good
Friday](/wiki/Good_Friday "Good Friday"), which ultimately culminates in the
joyful celebration on [Easter Sunday](/wiki/Easter_Sunday "Easter Sunday") of
the [Resurrection of Jesus Christ](/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus_Christ
"Resurrection of Jesus Christ").

In Lent, many Christians commit to [fasting](/wiki/Fasting "Fasting"), as well
as giving up certain [luxuries](/wiki/Luxury_goods "Luxury goods") in order to
replicate the sacrifice of Jesus Christ's journey [into the
desert](/wiki/Life_of_Jesus_in_the_New_Testament "Life of Jesus in the New
Testament") for 40 days.[7][8][9] Many Christians also add a Lenten spiritual
discipline, such as reading a [daily devotional](/wiki/Daily_devotional "Daily
devotional") or praying through a [Lenten calendar](/wiki/Lenten_calendar
"Lenten calendar"), to draw themselves near to God.[10][11] The [Stations of
the Cross](/wiki/Stations_of_the_Cross "Stations of the Cross"), a devotional
commemoration of [Christ's carrying the Cross](/wiki/Christ_Carrying_the_Cross
"Christ Carrying the Cross") and of [his execution](/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus
"Crucifixion of Jesus"), are often observed. Many [Roman
Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic") and some
[Protestant](/wiki/Protestant "Protestant") churches remove flowers from their
altars, while [crucifixes](/wiki/Crucifixes "Crucifixes"), religious statues,
and other elaborate religious symbols are often veiled in violet fabrics in
solemn observance of the event. Throughout [Christendom](/wiki/Christendom
"Christendom"), some adherents mark the season with the traditional abstention
from the consumption of meat, most notably among Lutherans, Roman Catholics
and Anglicans.[12][13][14]

Lent is traditionally described as lasting for 40 days, in commemoration of
the [40 days Jesus spent fasting in the desert](/wiki/Temptation_of_Jesus
"Temptation of Jesus"), according to the Gospels of
[Matthew](/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew "Gospel of Matthew"),
[Mark](/wiki/Gospel_of_Mark "Gospel of Mark") and [Luke](/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke
"Gospel of Luke"), before beginning his [public
ministry](/wiki/Ministry_of_Jesus "Ministry of Jesus"), during which he
endured temptation by [Satan](/wiki/Satan "Satan").[15][16]

Holy Week and the season of Lent, depending on the Christian denomination and
local custom, end with Easter Vigil at sundown on Holy Saturday, on the
morning of Easter Sunday, or at the midnight between them.

## Etymology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Etymology")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Holy_Week_procession_in_Granada%2C_Nicaragua.jpg/220px-
Holy_Week_procession_in_Granada%2C_Nicaragua.jpg)](/wiki/File:Holy_Week_procession_in_Granada,_Nicaragua.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Holy_Week_procession_in_Granada,_Nicaragua.jpg "Enlarge")

Lent celebrants carrying out a street procession during [Holy
Week](/wiki/Holy_Week "Holy Week"), in [Granada,
Nicaragua](/wiki/Granada,_Nicaragua "Granada, Nicaragua"). The violet color is
often associated with penance and [detachment](/wiki/Detachment_\(philosophy\)
"Detachment \(philosophy\)"). Similar Christian penitential practice is seen
in other [Christian countries](/wiki/Christian_countries "Christian
countries"), sometimes associated with [mortification of the
flesh](/wiki/Mortification_of_the_flesh "Mortification of the flesh").[17]

The English word _Lent_ is a shortened form of the [Old
English](/wiki/Old_English "Old English") word _len(c)ten_ , meaning "[spring
season](/wiki/Spring_\(season\) "Spring \(season\)")", as its [Dutch
language](/wiki/Dutch_language "Dutch language") cognate
_[lente](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lente#Dutch "wikt:lente")_ ([Old
Dutch](/wiki/Old_Dutch "Old Dutch") _lentin_)[18] still does today. A dated
term in [German](/wiki/German_language "German language"), _Lenz_ ([Old High
German](/wiki/Old_High_German "Old High German")
_[lenzo](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lenzo "wikt:lenzo")_), is also
related. According to the _[Oxford English
Dictionary](/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary "Oxford English Dictionary")_ ,
'the shorter form (? Old Germanic type *_laŋgito_ \- , *_laŋgiton_ -) seems to
be a derivative of *_laŋgo_ \- long ... and may possibly have reference to the
lengthening of the days as characterizing the season of spring'. The origin of
the -_en_ element is less clear: it may simply be a [suffix](/wiki/Suffix
"Suffix"), or _lencten_ may originally have been a compound of *_laŋgo_ \-
'long' and an otherwise little attested word *-_tino_ , meaning 'day'.[19]

In languages spoken where Christianity was earlier established, such as
[Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language") and [Latin](/wiki/Latin
"Latin"), the term signifies the period dating from the 40th day before
Easter. In modern Greek the term is _Σαρακοστή_ , derived from the earlier
_Τεσσαρακοστή_ , meaning "fortieth". The corresponding word in Latin,
_quadragesima_ ("fortieth"), is the origin of the term used in Latin-derived
languages and in some others: for example, [Croatian](/wiki/Croatian_language
"Croatian language") _korizma_ , French _carême_ ,
[Irish](/wiki/Irish_language "Irish language") _carghas_ , Italian _quaresima_
, [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language") _quaresma_ ,
[Albanian](/wiki/Albanian_language "Albanian language") _kreshma_ ,
[Romanian](/wiki/Romanian_language "Romanian language") _păresimi_ , Spanish
_cuaresma_ , [Basque](/wiki/Basque_language "Basque language") _garizuma_ and
[Welsh](/wiki/Welsh_language "Welsh language") _c(a)rawys_.

In other languages, the name used refers to the activity associated with the
season. Thus it is called "fasting period" in [Czech](/wiki/Czech_language
"Czech language") (_postní doba_), [German](/wiki/German_language "German
language") (_Fastenzeit_), and [Norwegian](/wiki/Norwegian_language "Norwegian
language") (_fasten_ /_fastetid_), and it is called "great fast" in
[Polish](/wiki/Polish_language "Polish language") (_wielki post_) and
[Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language") (великий пост – _veliki
post_).

The terms used in [Filipino](/wiki/Filipino_language "Filipino language") are
_kuwaresma_ (from the Spanish) and _Mahál na Araw_ ("precious/great days");
the latter term is also used specifically for Holy Week.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Duration and
traditions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section:
Duration and traditions")]

Various Christian [denominations](/wiki/Christian_denomination "Christian
denomination") calculate the 40 days of Lent differently. The way they observe
Lent also differs.

### Roman Catholicism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Roman Catholicism")]

In the Roman Rite Lent starts on Ash Wednesday and finishes on Holy Saturday.
This comprises a period of 46 days. This includes 6 Sundays which are not
considered part of Lent because Sundays are days of celebration for
Catholics.[20][_[not in citation given](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_]

In the [Ambrosian Rite](/wiki/Ambrosian_Rite "Ambrosian Rite"), Lent begins on
the Sunday that follows what is celebrated as Ash Wednesday in the rest of the
[Latin Catholic Church](/wiki/Latin_Church "Latin Church"), and ends as in the
Roman Rite, thus being of 40 days, counting the Sundays but not [Holy
Thursday](/wiki/Holy_Thursday "Holy Thursday"). The day for beginning the
Lenten fast is the following Monday, the first weekday in Lent. The special
Ash Wednesday fast is transferred to the first Friday of the Ambrosian Lent.
Until this rite was revised by Saint [Charles Borromeo](/wiki/Charles_Borromeo
"Charles Borromeo") the liturgy of the First Sunday of Lent was festive,
celebrated in white [vestments](/wiki/Vestment "Vestment") with chanting of
the [Gloria in Excelsis](/wiki/Gloria_in_Excelsis "Gloria in Excelsis") and
[Alleluia](/wiki/Alleluia_\(chant\) "Alleluia \(chant\)"), in line with the
recommendation in [Matthew 6:16](https://www.esv.org/Matthew+6:16), "When you
fast, do not look gloomy".[21][22][23]

The period of Lent observed in the [Eastern Catholic
Churches](/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches "Eastern Catholic Churches")
corresponds to that in other churches of [Eastern
Christianity](/wiki/Eastern_Christianity "Eastern Christianity") that have
similar traditions.

### Protestantism and Western
Orthodoxy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section:
Protestantism and Western Orthodoxy")]

In Protestant and Western Orthodox Churches, the season of Lent lasts from
[Ash Wednesday](/wiki/Ash_Wednesday "Ash Wednesday") to [Holy
Saturday](/wiki/Holy_Saturday "Holy Saturday").[24][25] This calculation makes
Lent last 46 days, if the 6 Sundays are included, but only 40, if they are
excluded,[26] This definition is still that of the [Anglican
Church](/wiki/Anglican_Communion "Anglican Communion"),[27] [Lutheran
Church](/wiki/Lutheran_World_Federation "Lutheran World Federation"),[28]
[Methodist Church](/wiki/World_Methodist_Council "World Methodist
Council"),[29] and [Western Rite Orthodox Church](/wiki/Western-
Rite_Orthodox_Churches "Western-Rite Orthodox Churches").[30]

### Eastern Orthodoxy and Byzantine
Rite[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section:
Eastern Orthodoxy and Byzantine Rite")]

Main article: [Great Lent](/wiki/Great_Lent "Great Lent")

In the [Byzantine Rite](/wiki/Byzantine_Rite "Byzantine Rite"), i.e., the
[Eastern Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church")
[Great Lent](/wiki/Great_Lent "Great Lent") (Greek: Μεγάλη Τεσσαρακοστή or
Μεγάλη Νηστεία, meaning "Great 40 Days" and "Great Fast" respectively) is the
most important fasting season in the church year.[31]

The 40 days of Great Lent includes Sundays, and begins on [Clean
Monday](/wiki/Clean_Monday "Clean Monday") and are immediately followed by
what are considered distinct periods of fasting, [Lazarus
Saturday](/wiki/Lazarus_Saturday "Lazarus Saturday") and [Palm
Sunday](/wiki/Palm_Sunday "Palm Sunday"), which in turn are followed
straightway by [Holy Week](/wiki/Holy_Week "Holy Week"). Great Lent is broken
only after the Paschal (Easter) Divine Liturgy.

The Eastern Orthodox Church maintains the traditional Church's teaching on
fasting. The rules for lenten fasting are the monastic rules. Fasting in the
Orthodox Church is more than simply abstaining from certain foods. During the
Great Lent Orthodox Faithful intensify their prayers and spiritual exercises,
go to church services more often, study the Scriptures and the works of the
[Church Fathers](/wiki/Church_Fathers "Church Fathers") in depth, limit their
entertainment and spendings and focus on charity and good works.

### Oriental Orthodoxy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Oriental Orthodoxy")]

Among the [Oriental Orthodox](/wiki/Oriental_Orthodoxy "Oriental Orthodoxy"),
there are various local traditions regarding Lent. Those using the
[Alexandrian Rite](/wiki/Alexandrian_Rite "Alexandrian Rite"), _i.e._ , the
[Coptic Orthodox](/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church_of_Alexandria "Coptic Orthodox
Church of Alexandria"), [Coptic Catholic](/wiki/Coptic_Catholic_Church "Coptic
Catholic Church"), [Ethiopian
Orthodox](/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox_Tewahedo_Church "Ethiopian Orthodox
Tewahedo Church"), [Ethiopian Catholic](/wiki/Ethiopian_Catholic_Church
"Ethiopian Catholic Church"), [Eritrean
Orthodox](/wiki/Eritrean_Orthodox_Tewahedo_Church "Eritrean Orthodox Tewahedo
Church"), and [Eritrean Catholic](/wiki/Eritrean_Catholic_Church "Eritrean
Catholic Church") Churches, observe eight weeks of Lent.

In Ethiopian Orthodoxy, fasting (_tsome_) lasts for 55 continuous days before
Easter (_[Fasika](/wiki/Fasika "Fasika")_), although the fast is divided into
three separate periods: Tsome Hirkal, eight days commemorating an early
Christian figure; Tsome Arba, 40 days of Lent; and Tsome Himamat, seven days
commemorating [Holy Week](/wiki/Holy_Week "Holy Week").[32][33][34] Fasting
involves abstention from animal products (meat, dairy, and eggs), and
refraining from eating or drinking before 3:00 pm.[32] Ethiopian devotees may
also abstain from sexual activity and the consumption of alcohol.[32]

As in the Eastern Orthodox Churches, the [date of Easter](/wiki/Computus
"Computus") is reckoned according to the [Julian
Calendar](/wiki/Julian_Calendar "Julian Calendar"), and usually occurs later
than Easter according to [Gregorian Calendar](/wiki/Gregorian_Calendar
"Gregorian Calendar") used by Catholic and Protestant Churches.

## Other related fasting
periods[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section:
Other related fasting periods")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/60/Ashes_to_Go_at_Palmer_Memorial_Episcopal_Church.jpg/250px-
Ashes_to_Go_at_Palmer_Memorial_Episcopal_Church.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ashes_to_Go_at_Palmer_Memorial_Episcopal_Church.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ashes_to_Go_at_Palmer_Memorial_Episcopal_Church.jpg "Enlarge")

The season of Lent begins on [Ash Wednesday](/wiki/Ash_Wednesday "Ash
Wednesday"), most notably by the public imposition of ashes. In this
photograph, a woman receives a cross of ashes on Ash Wednesday outside an
Anglican church.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Ash_Wednesday_Mass_at_Nazareth_Evangelical_Lutheran_Church.jpg/300px-
Ash_Wednesday_Mass_at_Nazareth_Evangelical_Lutheran_Church.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ash_Wednesday_Mass_at_Nazareth_Evangelical_Lutheran_Church.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ash_Wednesday_Mass_at_Nazareth_Evangelical_Lutheran_Church.jpg
"Enlarge")

A Lutheran pastor distributes ashes during the [Divine
Service](/wiki/Divine_Service_\(Lutheran\) "Divine Service \(Lutheran\)") on
Ash Wednesday.

The number 40 has many Biblical references:

  * [Moses](/wiki/Moses "Moses") spent 40 days on [Mount Sinai](/wiki/Biblical_Mount_Sinai "Biblical Mount Sinai") with [God](/wiki/God_in_Christianity "God in Christianity") ([Exodus 24:18](http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0224.htm#18))
  * [Elijah](/wiki/Elijah "Elijah") spent 40 days and nights walking to [Mount Horeb](/wiki/Mount_Horeb "Mount Horeb") ([1 Kings 19:8](http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt09a19.htm#8))
  * God sent 40 days and nights of rain in the great flood of [Noah](/wiki/Noah "Noah") ([Genesis 7:4](http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0107.htm#4))
  * The Hebrew people wandered 40 years in the desert while traveling to the [Promised Land](/wiki/Promised_Land "Promised Land") ([Numbers 14:33](http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0414.htm#33))
  * [Jonah](/wiki/Jonah "Jonah")'s prophecy of [judgment](/wiki/Judgment "Judgment") gave 40 days to the city of [Nineveh](/wiki/Nineveh "Nineveh") in which to repent or be destroyed ([Jonah 3:4](http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt1703.htm#4)).
  * Jesus retreated into the wilderness, where He fasted for 40 days, and was [tempted](/wiki/Temptation_of_Christ "Temptation of Christ") by the [devil](/wiki/Devil_in_Christianity "Devil in Christianity") ([Matthew 4:1–2](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(King_James\)/Matthew#4:1 "s:Bible \(King James\)/Matthew"), [Mark 1:12–13](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(King_James\)/Mark#1:12 "s:Bible \(King James\)/Mark"), [Luke 4:1–2](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(King_James\)/Luke#4:1 "s:Bible \(King James\)/Luke")). He overcame all three of Satan's [temptations](/wiki/Temptation "Temptation") by citing scripture to the devil, at which point the devil left him, angels ministered to Jesus, and He began His [ministry](/wiki/Christian_ministry "Christian ministry"). Jesus further said that His disciples should fast "when the bridegroom shall be taken from them" ([Matthew 9:15](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_\(King_James\)/Matthew#9:15 "s:Bible \(King James\)/Matthew")), a reference to his Passion.
  * Since, presumably, the Apostles fasted as they mourned the death of Jesus, Christians have traditionally fasted during the annual commemoration of his burial.
  * It is the traditional belief that Jesus laid for 40 hours in the tomb,[22] which led to the 40 hours of total fasting that preceded the Easter celebration in the [early Church](/wiki/Early_Christianity "Early Christianity")[35] (the biblical reference to 'three days in the tomb' is understood by them as _spanning_ three days, from Friday afternoon to early Sunday morning, rather than three 24-hour periods of time). Some Christian denominations, such as The Way International and Logos Apostolic Church of God,[36] as well as [Anglican](/wiki/Anglicanism "Anglicanism") scholar [E. W. Bullinger](/wiki/E._W._Bullinger "E. W. Bullinger") in _The Companion Bible_ , believe Christ was in the grave for a total of 72 hours, reflecting the [type](/wiki/Typology_\(theology\) "Typology \(theology\)") of Jonah in the belly of the whale.[37]

One of the most important ceremonies at Easter is the [baptism](/wiki/Baptism
"Baptism") of the initiates on Easter Eve. The fast was initially undertaken
by the [catechumens](/wiki/Catechumen "Catechumen") to prepare them for the
reception of this [sacrament](/wiki/Sacrament "Sacrament"). Later, the period
of fasting from [Good Friday](/wiki/Good_Friday "Good Friday") until Easter
Day was extended to six days, to correspond with the six weeks of training
necessary to give the final instruction to those
[converts](/wiki/Religious_conversion "Religious conversion") who were to be
baptized.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[Converts to Christianity](/wiki/Conversion_to_Christianity "Conversion to
Christianity") followed a strict [catechumenate](/wiki/Catechumenate
"Catechumenate") or period of instruction and discipline prior to receiving
the [sacrament](/wiki/Sacrament "Sacrament") of [baptism](/wiki/Baptism
"Baptism"), sometimes lasting up to three years.[38] In
[Jerusalem](/wiki/Jerusalem "Jerusalem") near the close of the fourth century,
classes were held throughout Lent for three hours each day. With the
legalization of Christianity (by the [Edict of Milan](/wiki/Edict_of_Milan
"Edict of Milan")) and its later imposition as the [state
religion](/wiki/State_religion "State religion") of the [Roman
Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire"), its character was endangered by
the great influx of new members. In response, the Lenten fast and practices of
[self-renunciation](/wiki/Asceticism#Christianity "Asceticism") were required
annually of all Christians, both to show solidarity with the catechumens, and
for their own spiritual benefit.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Associated customs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Associated customs")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Lenten_shrouds.jpeg/220px-
Lenten_shrouds.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Lenten_shrouds.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Lenten_shrouds.jpeg "Enlarge")

Statues and icons veiled in violet shrouds for [Passiontide](/wiki/Passiontide
"Passiontide") in [St Pancras Church,
Ipswich](/wiki/St_Pancras_Church,_Ipswich "St Pancras Church, Ipswich"),
England

There are traditionally 40 days in Lent; these are marked by fasting, both
from foods and festivities, and by other acts of [penance](/wiki/Penance
"Penance"). The three traditional practices to be taken up with renewed vigour
during Lent are [prayer](/wiki/Prayer "Prayer") ([justice](/wiki/Justice
"Justice") towards God), fasting (justice towards self), and
[almsgiving](/wiki/Almsgiving "Almsgiving") (justice towards neighbours).

However, in modern times, observers give up partaking in [vices](/wiki/Vice
"Vice") and often invest the time or money saved in
[charitable](/wiki/Charitable_cause "Charitable cause") purposes or
organizations.[39]

In addition, some believers add a regular spiritual discipline, to bring them
closer to God, such as reading a Lenten [daily
devotional](/wiki/Daily_devotional "Daily devotional").[10] Another practice
commonly added is the singing of the [Stabat Mater](/wiki/Stabat_Mater "Stabat
Mater") hymn in designated groups. Among Filipino Catholics, the recitation of
Jesus Christ' passion, called [Pasiong Mahal](/wiki/Pasiong_Mahal "Pasiong
Mahal"), is also observed. In some Christian countries, grand religious
processions and cultural customs are observed, and the faithful attempt to
[visit seven churches](/wiki/Seven_Churches_Visitation "Seven Churches
Visitation") during Holy Week in honor of Jesus Christ heading to [Mount
Calvary](/wiki/Mount_Calvary "Mount Calvary").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In many [liturgical](/wiki/Liturgy "Liturgy") [Christian
denominations](/wiki/Christian_denominations "Christian denominations"), [Good
Friday](/wiki/Good_Friday "Good Friday"), [Holy Saturday](/wiki/Holy_Saturday
"Holy Saturday"), and [Easter Sunday](/wiki/Easter_Sunday "Easter Sunday")
form the [Easter Triduum](/wiki/Easter_Triduum "Easter Triduum").[40] Lent is
a season of grief that necessarily ends with a great celebration of Easter.
Thus, it is known in [Eastern Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox "Eastern
Orthodox") circles as the season of "Bright Sadness". It is a season of
sorrowful [reflection](/wiki/Introspection "Introspection") which is
punctuated by breaks in the fast on Sundays.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Omission of Gloria and
Alleluia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section:
Omission of Gloria and Alleluia")]

The _[Gloria in excelsis Deo](/wiki/Gloria_in_excelsis_Deo "Gloria in excelsis
Deo")_ , which is usually said or sung on Sundays at
[Mass](/wiki/Mass_\(liturgy\) "Mass \(liturgy\)") of the [Roman
Rite](/wiki/Roman_Rite "Roman Rite") and Anglican rite, is omitted on the
Sundays of Lent, but continues in use on [solemnities](/wiki/Solemnity
"Solemnity") and [feasts](/wiki/Ranking_of_liturgical_days_in_the_Roman_Rite
"Ranking of liturgical days in the Roman Rite") and on special celebrations of
a more solemn kind.[41] Some [mass compositions](/wiki/Mass_\(music\) "Mass
\(music\)") were written especially for Lent, such as Michael Haydn's _[Missa
tempore Quadragesimae](/wiki/Missa_tempore_Quadragesimae_\(Michael_Haydn\)
"Missa tempore Quadragesimae \(Michael Haydn\)")_ , without Gloria, in D
minor, and for modest forces, only choir and organ. The Gloria is used on
[Maundy Thursday](/wiki/Maundy_Thursday "Maundy Thursday"), to the
accompaniment of bells, which then fall silent until the _Gloria in excelsis_
of the [Easter Vigil](/wiki/Easter_Vigil "Easter Vigil").[42]

The Lutheran [Divine Service](/wiki/Divine_Service_\(Lutheran\) "Divine
Service \(Lutheran\)"), the Roman Rite of the Catholic Church, and the
Presbyterian service of worship associate the _[Alleluia](/wiki/Alleluia
"Alleluia")_ with joy and omits it entirely throughout Lent,[43][44] not only
at Mass but also in the [canonical hours](/wiki/Canonical_hours "Canonical
hours") as well as outside the liturgy. Before 1970, the omission began with
[Septuagesima](/wiki/Septuagesima "Septuagesima"). The word "Alleluia" at the
beginning and end of the Acclamation Before the
[Gospel](/wiki/Gospel_\(liturgy\) "Gospel \(liturgy\)") at Mass is replaced by
another phrase. Before 1970, the whole Acclamation was omitted and was
replaced by a [Tract](/wiki/Tract_\(liturgy\) "Tract \(liturgy\)"). Again,
before 1970, the word "Alleluia" normally added to the _[Gloria
Patri](/wiki/Gloria_Patri "Gloria Patri")_ at the beginning of each Hour of
the Liturgy of the Hours was replaced by the phrase _Laus tibi, Domine, rex
aeternae gloriae_ (Praise to you, O Lord, king of eternal glory). Now it is
simply omitted.

Until the [Ambrosian Rite](/wiki/Ambrosian_Rite "Ambrosian Rite") was revised
by Saint [Charles Borromeo](/wiki/Charles_Borromeo "Charles Borromeo") the
liturgy of the First Sunday of Lent was festive, celebrated with chanting of
the Gloria and Alleluia, in line with the recommendation in [Matthew
6:16](https://www.esv.org/Matthew+6:16), "When you fast, do not look
gloomy".[21][22][23]

In the [Byzantine Rite](/wiki/Byzantine_Rite "Byzantine Rite"), the Gloria
([Great Doxology](/wiki/Great_Doxology "Great Doxology")) continues to be used
in its normal place in the [Matins](/wiki/Matins "Matins") service, and the
Alleluia appears all the more frequently, replacing "God is the Lord" at
Matins.

## Veiling of religious
images[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section:
Veiling of religious images")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e6/Minister_prostrates_at_the_start_of_United_Methodist_Good_Friday_liturgy.jpg/220px-
Minister_prostrates_at_the_start_of_United_Methodist_Good_Friday_liturgy.jpg)](/wiki/File:Minister_prostrates_at_the_start_of_United_Methodist_Good_Friday_liturgy.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Minister_prostrates_at_the_start_of_United_Methodist_Good_Friday_liturgy.jpg
"Enlarge")

A United Methodist minister [prostrates](/wiki/Prostration "Prostration") at
the start of the [Good Friday](/wiki/Good_Friday "Good Friday") liturgy at
Holy Family Church, in accordance with the rubrics in the [Book of
Worship](/wiki/The_United_Methodist_Book_of_Worship_\(1992\) "The United
Methodist Book of Worship \(1992\)"). The [processional
cross](/wiki/Processional_cross "Processional cross") is veiled in black, the
liturgical colour associated with Good Friday in Methodist Churches.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/StMartin43-53.JPG/220px-
StMartin43-53.JPG)](/wiki/File:StMartin43-53.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:StMartin43-53.JPG "Enlarge")

A [crucifix](/wiki/Crucifix "Crucifix") on the high altar is veiled for Lent.
Saint Martin's parish, [Württemberg](/wiki/W%C3%BCrttemberg "Württemberg"),
Germany

In certain pious [Christian states](/wiki/Christian_state "Christian state"),
in which liturgical forms of Christianity predominate, religious objects were
traditionally veiled for the entire 40 days of Lent. Though perhaps uncommon
in the United States of America, this pious practice is consistently observed
in [Goa](/wiki/Goa,_India "Goa, India"), Malta, Peru, the Philippines (the
latter only for the entire duration of Holy Week, with the exception of
processional images), and in the Spanish cities: [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona
"Barcelona"), [Málaga](/wiki/M%C3%A1laga "Málaga"), and
[Seville](/wiki/Seville "Seville"). In Ireland, before [Vatican
II](/wiki/Vatican_II "Vatican II"), when impoverished rural Catholic convents
and parishes could not afford purple fabrics, they resorted to either removing
the statues altogether or, if too heavy or bothersome, turned the statues to
face the wall. As is popular custom, the 14 [Stations of the
Cross](/wiki/Stations_of_the_Cross "Stations of the Cross") plaques on the
walls are not veiled.

Crucifixes made before the time of [Saint Francis of
Assisi](/wiki/Saint_Francis_of_Assisi "Saint Francis of Assisi") did not have
a corpus (body of Christ) and therefore were adorned with jewels and
gemstones, which was referred to as _Crux Gemmatae_. To keep the faithful from
adoring the crucifixes elaborated with ornamentation, veiling it in royal
purple fabrics came into place. The violet colour later evolved as a color of
penance and mourning.

Further liturgical changes in modernity reduced such observances to the last
week of [Passiontide](/wiki/Passiontide "Passiontide"). In parishes that could
afford only small quantities of violet fabrics, only the heads of the statues
were veiled. If no violet fabrics could be afforded at all, then the religious
statues and images were turned around facing the wall. Flowers were always
removed as a sign of solemn mourning.

In the [pre-1992 Methodist
liturgy](/wiki/Book_of_Worship_for_Church_and_Home_\(1965\) "Book of Worship
for Church and Home \(1965\)") and pre-1970 forms of the Roman Rite, the last
two weeks of Lent are known as [Passiontide](/wiki/Passiontide "Passiontide"),
a period beginning on the Fifth Sunday in Lent, which in the 1962 edition of
the [Roman Missal](/wiki/Roman_Missal "Roman Missal") is called the First
Sunday in Passiontide and in earlier editions Passion Sunday. All statues (and
in England paintings as well) in the church were traditionally veiled in
violet. This was seen as in keeping with the Gospel of that Sunday ([John
8:46–59](http://bible.oremus.org/?passage=John+8:46–59:46&version=nrsv)), in
which Jesus "hid himself" from the people.

Within many churches in the United States of America, after the Second Vatican
Council, the need to veil statues or crosses became increasingly irrelevant
and was deemed unnecessary by some [diocesan](/wiki/Diocesan "Diocesan")
bishops. As a result, the veils were removed at the singing of the [Gloria in
Excelsis Deo](/wiki/Gloria_in_Excelsis_Deo "Gloria in Excelsis Deo") during
the Easter Vigil. In 1970, the name "Passiontide" was dropped, although the
last two weeks are markedly different from the rest of the season, and
continuance of the tradition of veiling images is left to the discretion of a
country's conference of bishops or even to individual parishes as pastors may
wish.

On [Good Friday](/wiki/Good_Friday "Good Friday"), the Anglican, Lutheran, and
Methodist churches traditionally veiled "all pictures, statutes, and the cross
are covered in mourning black", while "the chancel and altar coverings are
replaced with black, and altar candles are extinguished". The fabrics are then
"replaced with white on [sunrise](/wiki/Sunrise "Sunrise") on [Easter
Sunday](/wiki/Easter_Sunday "Easter Sunday")".[45]

## Pre-Lenten festivals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Pre-Lenten festivals")]

Main article: [Shrovetide](/wiki/Shrovetide "Shrovetide")

Further information: [Carnival](/wiki/Carnival "Carnival"), [Mardi
Gras](/wiki/Mardi_Gras "Mardi Gras"), [Swabian-Alemannic-
Fastnacht](/wiki/Swabian-Alemannic-Fastnacht "Swabian-Alemannic-Fastnacht"),
[Maslenitsa](/wiki/Maslenitsa "Maslenitsa"), [Pancake Day](/wiki/Pancake_Day
"Pancake Day"), and [Baklahorani](/wiki/Baklahorani "Baklahorani")

The carnival celebrations which in many cultures traditionally precede Lent
are seen as a last opportunity for excess before Lent begins. Some of the most
famous are the [Carnival of Barranquilla](/wiki/Carnival_of_Barranquilla
"Carnival of Barranquilla"), the [Carnival of Santa Cruz de
Tenerife](/wiki/Carnival_of_Santa_Cruz_de_Tenerife "Carnival of Santa Cruz de
Tenerife"), the [Carnival of Venice](/wiki/Carnival_of_Venice "Carnival of
Venice"), [Cologne Carnival](/wiki/Cologne_Carnival "Cologne Carnival"), the
[New Orleans Mardi Gras](/wiki/New_Orleans_Mardi_Gras "New Orleans Mardi
Gras"), the [Rio de Janeiro carnival](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_carnival "Rio de
Janeiro carnival"), and the [Trinidad and Tobago
Carnival](/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago_Carnival "Trinidad and Tobago Carnival").

The day immediately preceding Lent is variously called [Mardi
Gras](/wiki/Mardi_Gras "Mardi Gras") ("[Fat Tuesday](/wiki/Fat_Tuesday "Fat
Tuesday")"), [Pancake Tuesday](/wiki/Pancake_Tuesday "Pancake Tuesday"), or
[Shrove Tuesday](/wiki/Shrove_Tuesday "Shrove Tuesday"). Sometimes, it is the
peak of the pre-Lenten festival, while sometimes it is largely occupied with
preparations for Lent. The observances vary from culture to culture, and even
from town to town.

Originally, in Lebanon and Syria, the last Thursday preceding Lent was called
"Khamis el zakara". For Catholics, it was meant to be a day of remembrance of
the dead ones. However, _zakara_ (which means "remembrance", in Arabic) was
gradually replaced by _sakara_ (meaning "getting drunk" in Arabic), and so the
occasion came to be known as _[Khamis el sakara](/wiki/Khamis_el_sakara
"Khamis el sakara")_ , wherein celebrants indulge themselves with [alcoholic
beverages](/wiki/Alcoholic_beverage "Alcoholic beverage").

## Fasting and
abstinence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Fasting and abstinence")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Brooklyn_Museum_-
_Jesus_Tempted_in_the_Wilderness_%28J%C3%A9sus_tent%C3%A9_dans_le_d%C3%A9sert%29_-_James_Tissot_-
_overall.jpg/220px-Brooklyn_Museum_-
_Jesus_Tempted_in_the_Wilderness_%28J%C3%A9sus_tent%C3%A9_dans_le_d%C3%A9sert%29_-_James_Tissot_-
_overall.jpg)](/wiki/File:Brooklyn_Museum_-
_Jesus_Tempted_in_the_Wilderness_\(J%C3%A9sus_tent%C3%A9_dans_le_d%C3%A9sert\)_-_James_Tissot_-
_overall.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Brooklyn_Museum_-
_Jesus_Tempted_in_the_Wilderness_\(J%C3%A9sus_tent%C3%A9_dans_le_d%C3%A9sert\)_-_James_Tissot_-
_overall.jpg "Enlarge")

_Jesus Tempted in the Wilderness (Jésus tenté dans le désert)_ , [James
Tissot](/wiki/James_Tissot "James Tissot"), [Brooklyn
Museum](/wiki/Brooklyn_Museum "Brooklyn Museum")

Further information: [Christian dietary laws](/wiki/Christian_dietary_laws
"Christian dietary laws")

Fasting during Lent was more prominent in ancient times than today. [Socrates
Scholasticus](/wiki/Socrates_Scholasticus "Socrates Scholasticus") reports
that in some places, all animal products were strictly forbidden, while
various others permitted fish, or fish and fowl, others prohibited fruit and
eggs, and still others permitted only bread. In many places, the observant
abstained from food for a whole day until the evening, and at sunset, Western
Christians traditionally broke the Lenten fast, which was often known as the
[Black Fast](/wiki/Black_Fast "Black Fast").[46][47] In [India](/wiki/India
"India") and [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan"), many Christians continue
this practice of fasting until sunset on [Ash Wednesday](/wiki/Ash_Wednesday
"Ash Wednesday") and [Good Friday](/wiki/Good_Friday "Good Friday"), with some
fasting in this manner throughout the whole season of Lent.[48]

For other Latin Catholics, by the early 20th century the theoretical
obligation of the penitential fast throughout Lent except on Sundays was to
take only one full meal a day. In addition, a smaller meal, called a
[collation](/wiki/Collation_\(meal\) "Collation \(meal\)"), was allowed in the
evening, and a cup of some beverage, accompanied by a little bread, in the
morning. In practice, this obligation, which was a matter of custom rather
than of written law, was not observed strictly.[49] The [1917 Code of Canon
Law](/wiki/1917_Code_of_Canon_Law "1917 Code of Canon Law") allowed the full
meal on a fasting day to be taken at any hour and to be supplemented by two
collations, with the quantity and the quality of the food to be determined by
local custom. The Lenten fast ended on [Holy Saturday](/wiki/Holy_Saturday
"Holy Saturday") at noon. Only those aged 21 to 59 were obliged to fast. As
with all merely ecclesiastical laws, particular difficulties, such as
strenuous work or illness, excused one from observance, and a dispensation
from the law could be granted by a bishop or parish priest. In addition to
fasting, abstinence from meat was to be observed on Ash Wednesday and on
Fridays and Saturdays in Lent.[50] A rule of thumb is that the two collations
should not add up to the equivalent of another full meal. Rather portions were
to be: "sufficient to sustain strength, but not sufficient to satisfy
hunger".[51] The [apostolic constitution](/wiki/Apostolic_constitution
"Apostolic constitution") _Paenitemini_ of 17 February 1966 reduced the
fasting days to two: Ash Wednesday and Good Friday, and allowed [episcopal
conferences](/wiki/Episcopal_conference "Episcopal conference") to "substitute
abstinence and fast wholly or in part with other forms of penitence and
especially works of charity and the exercises of piety".[52] This was made
part of the [1983 Code of Canon Law](/wiki/1983_Code_of_Canon_Law "1983 Code
of Canon Law"), which made obligatory fasting for those aged between 18 and
59, and abstinence for those aged 14 and upward.[53] The [Irish Catholic
Bishops' Conference](/wiki/Irish_Catholic_Bishops%27_Conference "Irish
Catholic Bishops' Conference") decided to allow other forms of Friday penance
to replace that of abstinence from meat, whether in Lent or outside Lent,
suggesting alternatives such as abstaining from some other food, or from
alcohol or smoking; making a special effort at participating in family prayer
or in Mass; making the [Stations of the Cross](/wiki/Stations_of_the_Cross
"Stations of the Cross"); or helping the poor, sick, old, or lonely.[54] The
[Catholic Bishops' Conference of England and
Wales](/wiki/Catholic_Bishops%27_Conference_of_England_and_Wales "Catholic
Bishops' Conference of England and Wales") made a similar ruling in 1985[55]
but decided in 2011 to restore the traditional year-round Friday abstinence
from meat.[56] The [United States Conference of Catholic
Bishops](/wiki/United_States_Conference_of_Catholic_Bishops "United States
Conference of Catholic Bishops") has maintained the rule of abstention from
meat on Friday only during Lent.[57]

Many Lutheran Churches advocate fasting during designated times such as
Lent,[9][58] especially on Ash Wednesday and Good Friday.[59][9][60][61] _A
Handbook for the Discipline of Lent_ delineates the following Lutheran fasting
guidelines:[12]

>   1. Fast on Ash Wednesday and Good Friday with only one simple meal during
> the day, usually without meat.
>   2. Refrain from eating meat (bloody foods) on all Fridays in Lent,
> substituting fish for example.
>   3. Eliminate a food or food group for the entire season. Especially
> consider saving rich and fatty foods for Easter.
>   4. Consider not eating before receiving Communion in Lent.
>   5. Abstain from or limit a favorite activity (television, movies, etc.)
> for the entire season, and spend more time in prayer, Bible study, and
> reading devotional material.[12]
>

The historic Methodist homilies regarding the [Sermon on the
Mount](/wiki/Sermon_on_the_Mount "Sermon on the Mount") stress the importance
of the Lenten fast, which begins on Ash Wednesday.[62] The United Methodist
Church therefore states that:

> There is a strong biblical base for fasting, particularly during the 40 days
> of Lent leading to the celebration of Easter. Jesus, as part of his
> spiritual preparation, went into the wilderness and fasted 40 days and 40
> nights, according to the Gospels.[63]

[Good Friday](/wiki/Good_Friday "Good Friday"), which is towards the end of
the Lenten season, is traditionally an important day of communal fasting for
Methodists.[64] Rev. Jacqui King, the minister of Nu Faith Community United
Methodist Church in Houston explained the philosophy of fasting during Lent as
"I'm not skipping a meal because in place of that meal I'm actually dining
with God".[65]

Many of the Churches in the Reformed tradition retained the Lenten fast in its
entirety.[8] The [Reformed Church in America](/wiki/Reformed_Church_in_America
"Reformed Church in America") describes the first day of Lent, [Ash
Wednesday](/wiki/Ash_Wednesday "Ash Wednesday"), as a day "focused on prayer,
fasting, and repentance" and considers fasting a focus of the whole Lenten
season,[66] as demonstrated in the "Invitation to Observe a Lenten
Discipline", found in the Reformed liturgy for the Ash Wednesday service,
which is read by the presider:[67]

> We begin this holy season by acknowledging our need for repentance and our
> need for the love and forgiveness shown to us in Jesus Christ. I invite you,
> therefore, in the name of Christ, to observe a Holy Lent, by self-
> examination and penitence, by prayer and fasting, by practicing works of
> love, and by reading and reflecting on God's Holy Word.[67]

[Good Friday](/wiki/Good_Friday "Good Friday"), which is towards the end of
the Lenten season, is traditionally an important day of communal fasting for
adherents of the Reformed faith.[64]

During the [early Middle Ages](/wiki/Early_Middle_Ages "Early Middle Ages"),
eggs, dairy products, and meat were generally forbidden. In favour of the
traditional practice, observed both in East and West, [Thomas
Aquinas](/wiki/Thomas_Aquinas "Thomas Aquinas") argued that "they afford
greater pleasure as food [than fish], and greater nourishment to the human
body, so that from their consumption there results a greater surplus available
for seminal matter, which when abundant becomes a great incentive to
lust."[68] Aquinas also authorized the consumption of [candy](/wiki/Candy
"Candy") during Lent, because "sugared spices" (such as
[comfits](/wiki/Comfits "Comfits")) were, in his opinion, digestive aids on
par with medicine rather than food.[69]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Bruegel_Lent.jpg/220px-
Bruegel_Lent.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bruegel_Lent.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bruegel_Lent.jpg "Enlarge")

[Jousting](/wiki/Jousting "Jousting") against [Carnival](/wiki/Carnival
"Carnival") is represented by a fat man on a beer barrel who wears a huge meat
pie as headdress; Lent is represented by a thin gaunt woman on a cart (shown
here) bearing Lenten fare: mussels, pretzels, and waffles. Oil painting _[The
Fight Between Carnival and Lent](/wiki/The_Fight_Between_Carnival_and_Lent
"The Fight Between Carnival and Lent")_ by [Pieter Bruegel the
Elder](/wiki/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder "Pieter Bruegel the Elder") (circa
1558–1559).

In Spain, the bull of the Holy [Crusade](/wiki/Crusade "Crusade") (renewed
periodically after 1492) allowed the consumption of dairy products[70] and
eggs during Lent in exchange for a contribution to the cause of the crusade.

[Giraldus Cambrensis](/wiki/Giraldus_Cambrensis "Giraldus Cambrensis"), in his
_Itinerary of Archbishop Baldwin through Wales_ , reports that "in Germany and
the [arctic](/wiki/Arctic "Arctic") regions", "great and religious persons"
eat the tail of [beavers](/wiki/Beaver "Beaver") as "fish" because of its
superficial resemblance to "both the taste and colour of fish". The animal was
very abundant in Wales at the time.[71]

In current Western societies the practice is considerably relaxed, though in
the Eastern Orthodox, [Oriental Orthodox](/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox "Oriental
Orthodox"), and [Eastern Catholic Churches](/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Church
"Eastern Catholic Church"), abstinence from all animal products including
eggs, fish, fowl, and milk sourced from animals (e.g., cows and goats, as
opposed to the milk of coconuts and soy beans) is still commonly practiced, so
that, where this is observed, only vegetarian (or [vegan](/wiki/Vegan
"Vegan")) meals are consumed for the whole of Lent, 45 days in the [Byzantine
Rite](/wiki/Byzantine_Rite "Byzantine Rite").

In the [Western](/wiki/Latin_Church "Latin Church") Catholic Church, the
obligation to fast no longer applies to all weekdays of Lent (40 days), but
only to Ash Wednesday and Good Friday. In the tradition of this part of the
Catholic Church, abstinence from eating some form of food (generally meat, but
not dairy or fish products) is distinguished from fasting. Fasting involves
having during the day only one proper meal with up to two "collations",[72]
light meatless meals sufficient to maintain strength but not adding up to the
equivalent of a full meal.[73] In principle, abstinence is to be observed on
Ash Wednesday and on every Friday of the year that is not a
[solemnity](/wiki/Solemnity "Solemnity") (a liturgical feast day of the
highest rank); but in each country the [episcopal
conference](/wiki/Episcopal_conference "Episcopal conference") can determine
the form it is to take, perhaps replacing abstinence with other forms of
penance.[53][74][75]

Present canonical legislation on these matters follows the 1966 [Apostolic
Constitution](/wiki/Apostolic_Constitution "Apostolic Constitution") of [Pope
Paul VI](/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI "Pope Paul VI"), _[Paenitemini](/wiki/Paenitemini
"Paenitemini")_ , in which he recommended that fasting be appropriate to the
local economic situation and that all Catholics voluntarily fast and abstain.
He also allowed replacing fasting and abstinence with prayer and works of
charity in countries with a lower standard of living. The law of abstinence
binds those age 14 or over, and that of fast binds those who are at least 18
years of age and not yet 60.[53] The sick and those who have special needs are
excused, and dispensations can be granted by episcopal conferences or
individual bishops, which can be wider outside of Lent. Even during Lent, the
rule about solemnities holds, so that the obligation of Friday abstinence does
not apply on 19 and 25 March when, as usually happens, the solemnities of
[Saint Joseph](/wiki/Saint_Joseph%27s_Day#Catholic_traditions "Saint Joseph's
Day") and the [Annunciation](/wiki/Annunciation "Annunciation") are celebrated
on those dates. The same applies to [Saint Patrick's
Day](/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_Day "Saint Patrick's Day"), which is a solemnity
in the whole of Ireland as well as in dioceses that have [Saint
Patrick](/wiki/Saint_Patrick "Saint Patrick") as principal patron saint. In
some other places, too, where there are strong Irish traditions within the
Catholic community, a dispensation is granted for that day.[76] In [Hong
Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong"), where Ash Wednesday often coincides with
[Chinese New Year](/wiki/Chinese_New_Year "Chinese New Year") celebrations, a
dispensation is then granted from the laws of fast and abstinence, and the
faithful are exhorted to use some other form of penance.[73]

After the [Protestant Reformation](/wiki/Protestant_Reformation "Protestant
Reformation"), in the [Lutheran Church](/wiki/Lutheran_Church "Lutheran
Church"), "Church orders of the 16th century retained the observation of the
Lenten fast, and Lutherans have observed this season with a serene, earnest
attitude."[3] In the [Anglican Churches](/wiki/Anglican_Communion "Anglican
Communion"), the [Traditional Saint Augustine's Prayer Book: A Book of
Devotion for Members of the Anglican
Communion](/wiki/Saint_Augustine%27s_Prayer_Book "Saint Augustine's Prayer
Book"), a companion to the [Book of Common Prayer](/wiki/Book_of_Common_Prayer
"Book of Common Prayer"), states that fasting is "usually meaning not more
than a light breakfast, one full meal, and one half meal, on the forty days of
Lent".[13] It further states that "the major Fast Days of Ash Wednesday and
Good Friday, as the American Prayer-Book indicates, are stricter in
obligation, though not in observance, than the other Fast Days, and therefore
should not be neglected except in cases of serious illness or other necessity
of an absolute character."[77]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Legionarios_en_la_procesi%C3%B3n_de_El_Encuentro_%28Semana_Santa_en_Ceuta%2C_2012%29.jpg/220px-

In many Christian countries, [religious
processions](/wiki/Procession#Christian "Procession") during the season of
Lent are often accompanied by a military escort both for security and parade.
[Ceuta](/wiki/Ceuta "Ceuta"), Spain

Traditionally, on Sunday, and during the hours before sunrise and after
sunset, some Churches, such as Episcopalians, allow "breaks" in their Lent
promises. For Roman Catholics, the Lenten penitential season ends after the
[Easter Vigil](/wiki/Easter_Vigil "Easter Vigil")
[Mass](/wiki/Mass_\(liturgy\) "Mass \(liturgy\)"). Orthodox Christians also
break their fast after the [Paschal Vigil](/wiki/Paschal_Vigil "Paschal
Vigil"), a service which starts around 11:00 pm on Holy Saturday, and which
includes the Paschal celebration of the [Divine Liturgy](/wiki/Divine_Liturgy
"Divine Liturgy") of St. [John Chrysostom](/wiki/John_Chrysostom "John
Chrysostom"). At the end of the service, the priest blesses cheese, eggs,
flesh meats, and other items that the faithful have been abstaining from for
the duration of Great Lent.

Lenten traditions and liturgical practices are less common, less binding, and
sometimes non-existent among some liberal and progressive Christians, since
these generally do not emphasize [piety](/wiki/Piety "Piety") and the
[mortification of the flesh](/wiki/Mortification_of_the_flesh "Mortification
of the flesh") as a significant virtue.[78] A greater emphasis on anticipation
of [Easter Sunday](/wiki/Easter_Sunday "Easter Sunday") is often encouraged
more than the penitence of Lent or Holy Week.[79]

Some Christians as well as secular groups also interpret the Lenten fast in a
positive tone, not as renunciation but as contributing to causes such as
environmental stewardship and improvement of health.[80][81][82] Even some
[atheists](/wiki/Atheists "Atheists") find value in the Christian tradition
and observe Lent.[83]

## Media coverage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Media coverage")]

During Lent, [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC")'s [Radio Four](/wiki/Radio_Four "Radio
Four") normally broadcasts a series of programmes called the _[Lent
Talks](/wiki/Lent_Talks "Lent Talks")_.[84] These 15-minute programmes are
normally broadcast on a Wednesday and have featured various speakers, such as
[John Lennox](/wiki/John_Lennox "John Lennox").[85]

[Church of the Holy Sepulchre](/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre "Church of

There are several holy days within the season of Lent:

  * [Ash Wednesday](/wiki/Ash_Wednesday "Ash Wednesday") is the first day of Lent in [Western Christianity](/wiki/Western_Christianity "Western Christianity"), such as the [Lutheran Churches](/wiki/Lutheran_Church "Lutheran Church"), [Roman Rite](/wiki/Roman_Rite "Roman Rite") of the Catholic Church, [Methodist Churches](/wiki/Methodist_Church "Methodist Church"), [Reformed](/wiki/Reformed "Reformed") traditions, etc.
  * In the [Ambrosian Rite](/wiki/Ambrosian_Rite "Ambrosian Rite") and the [Mozarabic Rite](/wiki/Mozarabic_Rite "Mozarabic Rite"), there is no Ash Wednesday: Lent begins on the first Sunday and the fast begins on the first Monday.
  * The Sundays in Lent carry Latin names in German [Lutheranism](/wiki/Lutheranism "Lutheranism"), derived from the beginning of the Sunday's [introit](/wiki/Introit "Introit"). The first is called Invocabit, the second Reminiscere, the third Oculi, the fourth [Laetare](/wiki/Laetare_Sunday "Laetare Sunday"), the fifth Judica, the sixth [Palm Sunday](/wiki/Palm_Sunday "Palm Sunday").
  * The fourth Sunday in Lent, which marks the halfway point between Ash Wednesday and Easter Sunday, is referred to as [Laetare Sunday](/wiki/Laetare_Sunday "Laetare Sunday") by Anglicans, Roman Catholics, and many other Christians, because of the traditional Entrance Antiphon of the Mass. Due to the more "joyful" character of the day (since _laetare_ in Latin means "rejoice"), the priest, deacon, and subdeacon have the option of wearing vestments of a rose colour (pink) instead of violet.
  * Additionally, the fourth Lenten Sunday, [Mothering Sunday](/wiki/Mothering_Sunday "Mothering Sunday"), which has become known as Mother's Day in the United Kingdom and an occasion for honouring mothers of children, has its origin in a 16th-century celebration of the [Mother Church](/wiki/Mother_Church "Mother Church").
  * The fifth Sunday in Lent, also known in some denominations as [Passion Sunday](/wiki/Passion_Sunday "Passion Sunday") (and in some denominations also applies to [Palm Sunday](/wiki/Palm_Sunday "Palm Sunday")) marks the beginning of [Passiontide](/wiki/Passiontide "Passiontide").
  * The sixth Sunday in Lent, commonly called [Palm Sunday](/wiki/Palm_Sunday "Palm Sunday"), marks the beginning of [Holy Week](/wiki/Holy_Week "Holy Week"), the final week of Lent immediately preceding Easter.
  * Wednesday of Holy Week, [Holy Wednesday](/wiki/Holy_Wednesday "Holy Wednesday") (also sometimes known as [Spy Wednesday](/wiki/Spy_Wednesday "Spy Wednesday")) commemorates [Judas Iscariot](/wiki/Judas_Iscariot "Judas Iscariot")'s bargain to betray Jesus.[86][87][88]
  * Thursday of Holy Week is known as [Maundy Thursday](/wiki/Maundy_Thursday "Maundy Thursday") or Holy Thursday, and is a day Christians commemorate the [Last Supper](/wiki/Last_Supper "Last Supper") shared by Christ with his [disciples](/wiki/Disciple_\(Christianity\) "Disciple \(Christianity\)").
  * The next day is [Good Friday](/wiki/Good_Friday "Good Friday"), on which Christians remember Jesus' [crucifixion](/wiki/Crucifixion "Crucifixion"), death, and burial.

### Easter Triduum[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Easter Triduum")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **does not[cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this section](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). _(October 2014)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
In the Anglican, Lutheran, Old Catholic, Roman Catholic, and many other
churches, the [Easter Triduum](/wiki/Easter_Triduum "Easter Triduum") is a
three-day event that begins Maundy Thursday evening, with the entrance hymn of
the Mass of the Lord's Supper. After this celebration, the consecrated
[Hosts](/wiki/Host_\(liturgy\) "Host \(liturgy\)") are taken solemnly from the
altar to a place of reposition, where the faithful are invited to meditate in
the presence of the consecrated Hosts.This is the Church's response to Jesus'
question to the disciples sleeping in the [Garden of
Gethsemane](/wiki/Gethsemane "Gethsemane"), "Could you not watch with me one
hour?" On the next day, the liturgical commemoration of the Passion of Jesus
Christ is celebrated at 3 pm, unless a later time is chosen due to work
schedules.

This service consists of readings from the [Scriptures](/wiki/Bible "Bible"),
especially [John the Evangelist](/wiki/John_the_Evangelist "John the
Evangelist")'s account of the [Passion](/wiki/Passion_\(Christianity\)
"Passion \(Christianity\)") of Jesus, followed by prayers, veneration of the
cross of Jesus, and a communion service at which the hosts consecrated at the
evening Mass of the day before are distributed. The [Easter
Vigil](/wiki/Easter_Vigil "Easter Vigil") during the night between Holy
Saturday afternoon and Easter Sunday morning starts with the blessing of a
fire and a special candle, and with readings from Scripture associated with
[baptism](/wiki/Baptism "Baptism"). Then, the [Gloria in Excelsis
Deo](/wiki/Gloria_in_Excelsis_Deo "Gloria in Excelsis Deo") is sung, water is
blessed, baptism and [confirmation](/wiki/Confirmation "Confirmation") of
adults may take place, the people are invited to renew the promises of their
own baptism, and finally, Mass is celebrated in the usual way from the
Preparation of the Gifts onwards.

Holy Week and the season of Lent, depending on
[denomination](/wiki/Christian_denomination "Christian denomination") and
local [custom](/wiki/Convention_\(norm\) "Convention \(norm\)"), end with
Easter Vigil at sundown on Holy Saturday or on the morning of Easter Sunday.
It is custom for some churches to hold sunrise services which include open air
celebrations in some places.

## Vestments[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lent&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Vestments")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6b/Chancel_on_Maundy_Thursday.jpg/220px-
Chancel_on_Maundy_Thursday.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chancel_on_Maundy_Thursday.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Chancel_on_Maundy_Thursday.jpg "Enlarge")

The [chancel](/wiki/Chancel "Chancel") of a [Lutheran](/wiki/Lutheran
"Lutheran") church decorated with red [paraments](/wiki/Parament "Parament"),
the liturgical colour of the last week of Lent, [Holy Week](/wiki/Holy_Week
"Holy Week"), in the Lutheran and Anglican Churches[89]

In the Lutheran, Methodist, Reformed, Roman Catholic, and many Anglican
churches, the pastor's vestments are violet during the season of Lent. On the
fourth Sunday in Lent, rose-coloured (pink) vestments may be worn in lieu of
violet. Historically, black had also been used: [Pope Innocent
III](/wiki/Pope_Innocent_III "Pope Innocent III") declared black to be the
proper color for Lent, though [Durandus of Saint-
Pourçain](/wiki/Durandus_of_Saint-Pour%C3%A7ain "Durandus of Saint-Pourçain")
claims violet has preference over black.[90]

In some Anglican churches, a type of unbleached linen or muslin known as
"Lenten array" is worn during the first three weeks of Lent, crimson is worn
during Passiontide, and on holy days, the colour proper to the day is
worn.[91] In certain other Anglican churches, as an alternative to violet for
all of Lent except Holy Week and red beginning on Palm Sunday through Holy
Saturday, Lenten array, typically made of sackcloth such as burlap and trimmed
with crimson cloth, often velvet, is worn, even during Holy Week—since the
sackcloth represents penance and the crimson edges represent the Passion of
Christ. Even the veils that cover the altar crosses or crucifixes and statuary
(if any) are made of the same sackcloth with the crimson trim.
